title: Which are denser, stars or gas giant planets? - Quora

response.answer_text: Using our own solar system as a guide, it appears that stars, at least normal ones on the main sequence, are denser than some gas giant planets: Sun: 1.41 grams/cm3 Jupiter 1.33 “ “ Saturn 0.687 “ “ Other main sequence stars are thought to be of about the same density as our Sun. Of course there are more massive planets than Jupiter, but it seems that these are not normally larger than about 1 &1/2 times Jupiter’s radius. That means that that the largest normal planets, with about 3.4 times the mass of Jupiter could have have the same density as it does. More massive than that, and they would probably be denser than their stars. That shouldn’t be a problem for them, though. Recall that Earth is nearly four times as dense a the Sun.

It varies… Jupiter isn’t as dense as our Sun, but it’s denser than Sirius A. Generally, the larger the star, the less dense it is; gas giants also seem to vary quite a bit. Saturn is less dense than water - it would float if you could find a bathtub big enough, but it’s far denser than the star Rigel.
